<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 865, 89]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will use a balancing method to determine the mass of a metre ruler. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 260, 120]]<|/det|> Refer to Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 128, 922, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 267, 532, 285]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 298, 146, 316]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 298, 920, 346]]<|/det|> Place the metre ruler on the pivot. Place load U on the metre ruler with its centre at the \(5.0 \text{cm}\) mark. Keep load U at the \(5.0 \text{cm}\) mark and adjust the position of the metre ruler on the pivot until the metre ruler is as near to being balanced as possible. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 361, 920, 393]]<|/det|> The distance a between the centre of load U and the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark on the metre ruler is recorded in Table 1.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 408, 517, 425]]<|/det|> In Table 1.1, record the position of the pivot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 438, 918, 470]]<|/det|> Calculate and record in Table 1.1, the distance \(b\) between the centre of load U and the pivot. Use the formula \(b =\) (position of pivot – position of load U). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 484, 920, 516]]<|/det|> Repeat the procedure for positions of load U at the \(10.0 \text{cm}\), \(15.0 \text{cm}\), \(20.0 \text{cm}\) and \(25.0 \text{cm}\) marks. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 532, 539, 549]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[267, 562, 729, 718]]<|/det|>
position of load U/cma/cmposition of pivot/cmb/cm
5.045.0
10.040.0
15.035.0
20.030.0
25.025.0

<label>(b)</label>

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 621, 89]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(a / \text{cm}\) (y-axis) against \(b / \text{cm}\) (x-axis).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 85, 631, 103]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 117, 443, 135]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 604, 858, 631]]<|/det|>
Calculate the mass \(M\) of the metre ruler. Use the equation \(M = \frac{k}{G - 1}\) , where \(k = 25 \text{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 640, 363, 658]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 303, 920, 336]]<|/det|>
The accuracy of the result obtained by this procedure depends on the metre ruler, without a load, balancing with the pivot at the 50.0 cm mark.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 335, 920, 367]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 365, 784, 383]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 868, 91]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will determine the focal length of a converging lens by two methods.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 260, 120]]<|/det|>
Refer to Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 131, 233, 149]]<|/det|>
illuminated object

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 144, 915, 234]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 247, 532, 266]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 278, 144, 297]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 278, 507, 297]]<|/det|>
Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 308, 761, 327]]<|/det|>
Set the distance \(u\) between the illuminated object and the lens to \(20.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 325, 321, 344]]<|/det|>
Switch on the lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 355, 920, 390]]<|/det|>
Place the screen near the lens. Move the screen until a sharp image of the illuminated object is seen on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 402, 180, 420]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 402, 794, 421]]<|/det|>
Describe a technique for obtaining an image that is as sharp as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 494, 870, 512]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 524, 180, 543]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 524, 816, 543]]<|/det|>
Measure \(v\), the distance from the lens to the screen as indicated in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 555, 918, 574]]<|/det|>
<form>v = .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 586, 764, 606]]<|/det|>
Measure \(h_{\mathrm{O}}\), the height of the illuminated object, indicated in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 617, 920, 637]]<|/det|>
<form>h_{\mathrm{O}} = .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 648, 611, 667]]<|/det|>
Measure \(h_{\mathrm{I}}\), the height of the image on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 680, 920, 698]]<|/det|>
<form>h_{\mathrm{I}} = .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 695, 920, 714]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 712, 359, 730]]<|/det|>
Switch off the lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 695, 91]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the effect of insulation on the cooling of a liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which will enable her to investigate how changing the thickness of insulation surrounding a beaker affects the rate of cooling of hot water in the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 150, 470, 166]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to do the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 398, 198]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 214, 282, 229]]<|/det|>
· a glass beaker

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 228, 332, 244]]<|/det|>
· a supply of hot water

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 243, 332, 258]]<|/det|>
· a lid to fit the beaker

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 258, 515, 275]]<|/det|>
· strips of insulation which can be cut to size.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 289, 225, 306]]<|/det|>
In your plan:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 460, 337]]<|/det|>
· list any additional apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 351, 918, 384]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how to do the experiment, including the measurements to take so that the rate of cooling can be determined

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 399, 485, 415]]<|/det|>
· state the key variables to keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 429, 918, 462]]<|/det|>
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 476, 603, 493]]<|/det|>
· explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 506, 576, 523]]<|/det|>
You may draw a diagram if it helps to explain your plan.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 73, 561, 88]]<|/det|>
# BLANK PAGE
